document.title: Archdiocese of Milwaukee Curriculum Guide, Grade 8

82347202FCE54347A5A600AA7E9559E8.description: Approximately locate irrational numbers on a number line

2CE5D00A323B48C9AE4544517F6CF74A.description: Approximate irrational numbers as rational numbers

5BE6E4E4CB5C4815AD6E4BB91F827475.description: Estimate the value of expressions involving irrational numbers using rational approximations

1760674D2AB340D3AAB0FC7C3B1F84AC.description: Compare the size of irrational numbers using rational approximations

8009EE9F25C64F67B31E60BD07DA6A7A.description: Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions (e.g., π2). For example, by truncating the decimal expansion of √2, show that √2 is between 1 and 2, then between 1.4 and 1.5, and explain how to continue on to get better approximations.

7EAF3C2D82984747AE02142115718831.description: Show informally that every number has a decimal expansion

849DC5F358014EA7ACC7B00DE9BB407B.description: Convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number

2A67358C561D48728086929984877AB8.description: Show that the decimal expansion of rational numbers repeats eventually

759BD176D8C04089876301DF498264F5.description: Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion; for rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually, and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.

F3649B547E1042B9A598DA691E87502E.description: Use relative frequencies of the data to describe relationships (positive, negative, or no correlation)

C31D7387AA254A0FA0C1622FE55419B9.description: Interpret the data in the two-way table to recognize patterns

C15F3DC598A041E3972F02C0130D9C59.description: Know how to construct a two-way table

F57A54BA89584D48A236C19BDFF9EE1E.description: Recognize patterns shown in comparison of two sets of data

62F0A30F8A704A57A172373F49364427.description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables. For example, collect data from students in your class on whether or not they have a curfew on school nights and whether or not they have assigned chores at home. Is there evidence that those who have a curfew also tend to have chores?

4FEA86EBF2E245038A6A0688A4AED557.description: Find the slope and intercept of a linear equation

0FC8127AEBDB4414868F06ED8C6D92E6.description: Solve problems using the equation of a linear model

8173B92FEC34495F912DB47267D3B8BB.description: Interpret the meaning of slope and intercept of a linear equation in terms of the situation

BB54515818FF4649B67EB44122C47019.description: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept. For example, in a linear model for a biology experiment, interpret a slope of 1.5 cm/hr as meaning that an additional hour of sunlight each day is associated with an additional 1.5 cm in mature plant height.

66D9EC04FADD44E4A93840CB27EC4A74.description: Formulate a straight line within scatter plot data

A344CDFF6F7F4FCBBCE34858660A719C.description: Informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line

7D3578745B4545ED8AE7B0DCADC9E09F.description: Know straight lines are used to model relationships between two quantitative variables

A9A09998CAA548A5A29017C60043798A.description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.

59A3BB7E7B7341FEB5A378E02C0F841B.description: Construct scatter plots for bivariate measurement data

BF7B595AC09E43D389D0002C0033AE03.description:
Interpret scatter plots for bivariate (two different variables such as distance and time) measurement data to
investigate patterns of association between two quantities

FC58006BB6ED49D7A5D298075AEA1172.description:
Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear
association

E62D335E08C14081A2CBE39CB9BB3AFF.description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

766DFB2E070347B7AEC545A407F9F3F6.description: Given the volume of a cone, cylinder, or sphere, find the radii, height, or approximate using pi

737FC53D97F14E0F998CAEEC24BD4200.description:
Determine and apply appropriate volume formulas in order to solve mathematical and real-world problems for
the given shape

A5679225A8904684ABD65B45F15D21D3.description: Compare the volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres

7D05D0BC9B0D40618C799AB957FDD37E.description: Knows formulas for volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres

D8754F5610CB4B79AFDDE42BCE70D756.description:
Identify and define vocabulary: cone, cylinder, sphere, radius, diameter, circumference, area, volume, pi, base,
height

4A1BE30D06E24768AB7D571BF7190986.description: Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

7B0FEE7527654505A791A7D6CC3149E8.description: Use the Pythagorean Theorem to solve for the distance between the two points

979116B3873444CDB3322A89FC2BF476.description: Determine how to create a right triangle from two points on a coordinate graph

202DC38C27584EE4BB6B5A2ACA97EC6E.description: Recall the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse

EE7AF25670634DDA922468ED04D55445.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.

F84993C350E94292970AD2F7BA2F6300.description:
Solve basic mathematical Pythagorean Theorem problems and its converse to find missing lengths of sides of
triangles in two or three dimensions

AA4E791B865748E49FA999C38E2BC7AA.description: Apply Pythagorean Theorem in solving real-world problems dealing with two- and three-dimensional shapes

04B9C36A2F32402098F95190AD88547F.description: Recall the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse

4F327347568542C2AC3B25479AFD4321.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

4F6DDAE4FB774ADDBF2E0E47FB764E01.description: Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem

41F9C7C96CE748F6B5B858ECFCF54711.description: Identify the legs and hypotenuse of a right triangle

F721D4CF28614E4A98AD495A0C51FC94.description:
Define key vocabulary: square root, Pythagorean Theorem, right triangle, legs a & b, hypotenuse, sides, right
angle, converse, base, height, proof

336DA8A91373488DB88611853AF6D2A2.description: Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.

B38E4AA6540B4483A3D322A70B1892F2.description:
Use Angle-Angle Criterion to prove similarity among triangles (Give an argument in terms of transversals, why this
is so)

C5A22E1FB5FE4EA48BEB6227720AD04A.description: Justify that the exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two remote interior angles

C3D6EA521CB64581814F6263D61361C2.description: Justify that the sum of interior angles equals 180

3A2CE4D473444C3ABF4BA6D1A395D18C.description:
Identify angles created when a parallel line is cut by a transversal (alternate interior, alternate exterior,
corresponding, vertical, adjacent, etc.)

307672905E894364B9E0D20604189988.description: Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.

9CF254581A404F1BBCA6C6C7998049F1.description:
Reason that a 2-D figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained by a sequence of rotations, reflections,
translations, or dilation

0E090E2264484BF38F7A31F1208D6F53.description: Apply the concept of similarity to write similarity statements

B00F0BFD888F49C3B692A8228A4DF3A4.description: Describe the sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, or dilations that exhibits the similarity between 2-D figures using words and/or symbols

5B95797B4A33410D88B115E2748AF766.description: Define similar figures as corresponding angles are congruent and corresponding sides are proportional

77ED9AEFFFA94B8296E511BE40DD1692.description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the similarity between them.

BF2FF989D6D6484585895B5891DCA425.description: Describe the effects of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on 2-D figures using coordinates

C83C1FD14B7E4AF5AFE38AD4DF31A2F4.description: Identify scale factor of the dilation

B32F1CE840FC4C798538AF06FE71ADE4.description: Define dilations as a reduction or enlargement of a figure

C2679D4ECA794254B73BE72B5C6B771D.description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

2E868829C2F4487E804ED3E1C26C77A7.description:
Reason that a 2-D figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained by a sequence of rotations,
reflections, translations

E1F2395D644F48A7B9A2CADFC7C286EA.description: Apply the concept of congruency to write congruent statements

3F2552C2DF0B405CB6E5C9C50CD953B7.description:
Describe the sequence of rotations, reflections, translations that exhibits the congruence between 2-D figures
using words

CD5A1AF8C8444C97A5EF90AC285654F9.description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the congruence between them.

82B2195039564F4EBC26EDDA20A96D07.description:
Use physical models, transparencies, or geometry software to verify the properties of rotations, reflections, and
translations

F7DDA33CEA024C1E8413519F6BF9DAC4.description: Understand prime notation to describe an image after a translation, reflection, or rotation

34210A324E3F41BF8BA3CE71D293CE3F.description: Identify direction and degree of rotation

B4102C7E611F4B78B3CFF7E877A64379.description: Identify corresponding sides and corresponding angles

FE3254567AD6464597ECD19855B9BBB6.description: Define and identify rotations, reflections, and translations

E9B65123F4C94909BF43F06B41391912.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations

6CC42D8F254D43368F3EAF0D568D23CE.description: Sketch a graph, given a verbal description of its qualitative features

FEDDC60807E64C8EB0B061ECCE59AC8E.description: Interpret the relationship between x and y values by analyzing a graph

F08A75C3CEEE4A528DDA741458296026.description: Analyze a graph and describe the functional relationship between two quantities using the qualities of the graph

F611E0C283224CDD98DAFEDC3F38D5EA.description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

F2A7B79FAE4F4D18BC93B83A9B49EDDD.description:
Relate the rate of change and initial value to real-world quantities in a linear function in terms of the situation
modeled and in terms of its graph or a table of values

398FF6EE39364A289022078D1643EA13.description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities

1555E874011946E8B4BA4B6A5393D7F4.description: Determine the initial value from two (x, y) values, a verbal description, values in a table, or graph

2719D9533FF747D6BCE76A51199CFD1B.description: Determine the rate of change from two (x, y) values, a verbal description, values in a table, or graph

791BC2F664E84A7DB17D48C75433B930.description: Recognize that the y-intercept is the initial value where x=0

2C46F750BC694FA58AB31C1F46F364D7.description: Recognize that slope is determined by the constant rate of change

0AC1B444D0EF4591AEAC230C8A9B84F9.description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change  and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

19E33E6838BE41F88BA943EF0C686B61.description: Provide examples of nonlinear functions using multiple representations

7480EE84FB5B4365A5771A86458B1403.description: Compare the characteristics of linear and nonlinear functions using various representations

E39B205ECF7F44B78BFAE085C40318F5.description:
Recognize the equation y = mx + b is the equation of a function whose graph is a straight line where m is the slope
and b is the y-intercept

97C29233F509414F9B096F026698D7EC.description: Recognize that a linear function is graphed as a straight line

4F4958D712C94A869D2EA94AB9AF0BD4.description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear. For example, the function A = s2 giving the area of a square as a function of its side length is not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4) and (3,9), which are not on a straight line.

C08A206A5A6C4FA5BB4A13B40F4ADDD3.description: Draw conclusions based on different representations of functions

F76C4D6CE2374AFC886135AAEE6A1AEB.description: Compare and contrast two functions with different representations

B8332B6C382E4F3FB30AC6E3466F4F90.description: Identify functions using graphs, tables and verbal descriptions

1B7C57A2233F448C9A9B81FEC8855575.description: Identify functions algebraically including slope and y-intercept

BF709E39E98A43889DB856D0628E1394.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions). For example, given a linear function represented by a table of values and a linear function represented by an algebraic expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.

72760F07582443BD93A0E1B505F04B49.description: Solve simple cases of systems of two linear equations with two variables by inspection

F82F3F68C4FE4FC6BDF5E2C5970D05C8.description: Solve a system of two equations (linear) with two unknowns algebraically

902C708FF6F943E5B6D3558F63BB15C7.description: Estimate the point(s) of intersection for a system of two equations with two unknowns by graphing the equations

6F2CA651B23046C78D3D0CF76EE00A5E.description: Identify cases in which a system of two equations with two unknowns has an infinite number of solutions

203021F3192445278FD6D3B3AA63C5B5.description: Identify cases in which a system of two equations with two unknowns has no solution

815F3BF93F1548E5B207711E591E5497.description: Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.

5FBC9A6E5C3F4FF38BE2C2BC983008A6.description: Estimate the point(s) of intersection for a system of two equations with two unknowns by graphing the equations

81F34C2205BB4FBE8E2CBE96E3098E0B.description: Solve simple cases of systems of two linear equations with two variables by inspection

69F23E8070B64D37B4BCFDEF5D12BE7B.description: Solve a system of two equations (linear) with two unknowns algebraically

D144E430F50F4ACC8999584A7D0D29DA.description: Estimate the point(s) of intersection for a system of two equations with two unknowns by graphing the equations

49BC3EA3121641D987972959FBB70054.description: Identify cases in which a system of two equations with two unknowns has an infinite number of solutions

11D1CE9C419A4E74845267363C08F473.description: Identify cases in which a system of two equations with two unknowns has no solution

CEAB826740624C3D863F74C1D6B92629.description:
Identify the solution(s) to a system of two linear equations in two variables as the point(s) of intersection of their
graphs

B2FF818D4F544F74A32C528A7731EC32.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

908FFACDDEAD4054B3F79135287CAD31.description:
Show how to transform given equations into simpler forms, until the result is an equivalent equation of the form
x=a, a=a, or a=b

35BC20504F51485981B139F0B7655007.description: Solve equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and/or collecting like terms

F356981B65C0414099066DAC14137B8B.description: Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients

8A9FD0EDB87745E5AE1F3658E125403C.description: Identify examples of linear equations in one variable with no solution

E2DC9DE85F5F4192BC0CA52A0DDB41C1.description: Identify examples of linear equations in one variable with infinitely many solutions

811A87767C28445096C8A00469FF1715.description: Identify examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution

B5D9F1B8977546E3A48DA123512443F0.description: Solve linear equations in one variable.

A17BA266E33C4EFBA246BC56210A21C3.description:
Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line
in the coordinate plane

C689C8D901BF4438AFB1B4CBB122431B.description: Find the slope of a line

2272704B714D45ED8DADD24FE2682F23.description: Determine the y-intercept of a line

6B2E748B58DC4720B7EDDC254DA0DD9A.description: Derive an equation of the form y= mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b (the y-intercept)

5811438EE93E48EF91D9ACC3F26A0F46.description: Derive an equation of the form y = mx for a line through the origin

37681A09CC334BF990C442925C34D4BA.description: Analyze patterns for points on a line that does not pass through or include the origin

87D168A7F257474E9C69F2FFCEFB87F7.description: Analyze patterns for points on a line that passes through the origin

E494CF84553C4EA7AE6D8BE9174B80A2.description: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

F0F77B14D9044578808BFDC2498BC62C.description: Interpret the unit rate of proportional relationships as the slope of the graph

B14EC5C02F564C618B11BA0A0E0EE9EB.description: Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways

D4697A1842F04A7C874A0B0288B90D8B.description: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways. For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed.

E55A6557008E404385A3C8A9F325FEAC.description: Perform operations using numbers expressed in scientific notations

F1D98EFB28424F4E933A67710BDB6E00.description: Use scientific notation to express very large and very small quantities

45DC1E87D84F4BB9B7DF45F6294EB078.description: Choose appropriate units of measure when using scientific notation

10969FC413004A659CDF0ABB0BB0B42B.description: Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology

D0D7A81F6A904FEAB8EFD2BEC6C605FD.description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology

5453AA704A2E4264A56A356E50415DC5.description: Use scientific notation to estimate very large and/or very small quantities

D782AD7991E14D0AA801E3723E292993.description: Compare quantities to express how much larger one is compared to the other

DACA52C58959490E94F09C274F567D5D.description: Express numbers as a single digit times an integer power of 10

F38D43F4D7954E44B297603146502192.description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other. For example, estimate the population of the United States as 3 times 108 and the population of the world as 7 times 109, and determine that the world population is more than 20 times larger.

33C8F04A5E3F4F6F86EF9A23BCC22177.description:
Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3 = p, where p
is a positive rational number

6BE4EA177074450182F6B0956087DB11.description: Evaluate cube roots of small perfect cubes

0B7A24C566784327B2DD1C4BA9FE2EC2.description: Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares

26AF05DF8BC9470984C2566DE1C071FD.description: Know that the square root of 2 is irrational

44C32CB6AAAD4240B176033DFDFC7C2F.description: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3 = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that √2 is irrational.

EEA03DA37BFA412395C27EA725D66474.description: Apply the properties of integer exponents to produce equivalent numerical expressions

9B3488419C72433EA00A5CAE48643D67.description: Explain the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions

55AD12D5235944689C94E713F09318F6.description: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions. For example, 32 × 3-5 = 3-3 = 1/33 = 1/27.
